sections.title: Letter of Greeting to the Jews in Egypt
Account of God's Deliverance of Jerusalem

verses.text: The Jews residing in Jerusalem and throughout Judea send greetings and wish true peace to their brothers among the Jews living in Egypt.
verses.comment: This verse introduces the epistolary format of 2 Maccabees and establishes the audience as diaspora Jews in Egypt, suggesting active communication between Jewish communities.
verses.sectionHeader: Letter of Greeting to the Jews in Egypt

verses.text: May God give you His goodness, remembering His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—His loyal servants.
verses.comment: Recalls the Abrahamic covenant, stressing continuity between generations of faith; a frequent ancient motif when invoking God's favor.

verses.text: May He grant every one of you a heart devoted to worshiping Him and carrying out His will with unwavering commitment and willing spirit.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the internal, spiritual requirements for true worship—themes found throughout the Law and the Prophets.

verses.text: May He open your minds to understand His law and His commands, and grant you peace.
verses.comment: The prayer for understanding, combined with peace, highlights that obedience to the Law brings holistic wellbeing.

verses.text: May He listen to your prayers, restore His favor to you, and never abandon you in times of trouble.
verses.comment: Theological assurance of God's responsiveness during suffering, echoing the Psalms and prophetic writings.

verses.text: Know that we too are praying for you here.
verses.comment: Reinforces community solidarity and intercessory prayer among diaspora Jews.

verses.text: In the reign of Demetrius, in the year one hundred sixty-nine, we Jews wrote to you amid the dire circumstances that followed the rebellion led by Jason and his companions against the holy land and the kingdom.
verses.comment: References historical events, situating the letter during political turmoil under Demetrius (likely Demetrius I Soter). The revolt of Jason is described in 2 Macc 4.

verses.text: They set fire to the city gate and shed innocent blood. In response, we prayed to the Lord and He answered us. We offered burnt and grain offerings, kindled the lamps, and set the bread before Him.
verses.comment: Describes the turmoil and ritual restoration activities in the aftermath of violence.

verses.text: We now urge you: celebrate the Festival of Booths in the month of Chislev, in year one hundred eighty-eight.
verses.comment: Calls for the observance of a festival, likely relating to the rededication of the temple—Hanukkah's roots.

verses.text: The citizens of Jerusalem and Judea, together with the council and Judas, send greetings and wish good health to Aristobulus—descended from the priests anointed with oil, instructor to King Ptolemy—and to all the Jews in Egypt.
verses.comment: Formal greeting to the Jewish sage Aristobulus and other Jews, confirming the letter's authoritative and representative nature.
verses.sectionHeader: Account of God's Deliverance of Jerusalem

verses.text: After God rescued us from great danger, we gratefully praise Him for standing by us against the king.
verses.comment: Highlights God's intervention and the community's gratitude—thanksgiving after deliverance.

verses.text: He drove out those who attacked the holy city.
verses.comment: God's protective acts affirm Jerusalem's sanctity and status as the locus of divine favor.

verses.text: When the enemy commander entered Persia with a seemingly unstoppable army, they were slaughtered in the temple of Nanea through a clever scheme devised by the priests of her temple.
verses.comment: Historical note referencing Antiochus IV's death, interpreted as divine justice administered through pagan priests.

verses.text: Claiming he wished to marry the goddess, Antiochus entered the temple with his companions, attempting to claim most of its treasures as a dowry.
verses.comment: Ancient Near Eastern rulers sometimes appropriated sacred objects; here, Antiochus's claim demonstrates arrogance and sacrilege.

verses.text: The priests set out the valuables, and when Antiochus entered the enclosed sanctuary with only a few men, they shut the temple doors behind him.
verses.comment: Details the treacherous setup for Antiochus; note the dramatic enclosure within the sacred precinct.

verses.text: Then, opening a hidden doorway in the roof, the priests hurled stones down, striking the leader and his associates, cutting them up, beheading them, and tossing their bodies outside for the people.
verses.comment: Describes the grisly execution; the violence serves as retribution for sacrilege.

verses.text: Praise be to our God in all things, for He has rendered judgment upon the wicked.
verses.comment: A doxological statement affirming God's justice and righteousness.

verses.text: As we celebrate the ritual cleansing of the temple on the twenty-fifth day of Chislev, we felt it important to inform you, so that you too may keep the Festival of Booths and observe the festival of the miraculous fire that appeared when Nehemiah, who rebuilt the sanctuary and the altar, offered sacrifices.
verses.comment: Connects the Hanukkah festival to earlier traditions surrounding temple dedication and the miracle of fire.

verses.text: When our ancestors were taken captive to Persia, the devout priests secretly took fire from the altar and hid it in the hollow of a dry well, keeping its location secret from everyone.
verses.comment: Explains the preservation of sacred fire as a symbol of continuity and faithfulness under duress.

verses.text: Many years later, by God's providence, Nehemiah—commissioned by the Persian king—sent descendants of those priests to retrieve the hidden fire. But though they found only thick liquid, he instructed them to take it and bring it back.
verses.comment: The story introduces the miraculous transformation of liquid to fire, affirming God's supernatural involvement.

verses.text: When the items for the offering were set out, Nehemiah ordered the priests to sprinkle the liquid over the wood and the sacrifices.
verses.comment: Ritual instructions foreshadowing the manifestation of God's power.

verses.text: Once this was done and after a while had passed, the sun broke through the clouds, and a blazing fire erupted, astonishing everyone present.
verses.comment: God miraculously turns the liquid into fire—recalling similar events in Moses' time.

verses.text: While the burnt offering was being consumed, the priests, joined by all present, prayed in unison—Jonathan leading the prayer and the others responding, along with Nehemiah.
verses.comment: Community prayer enhances the solemnity and collective participation in the miracle.

verses.text: Their prayer was: “Lord, Lord God, the Creator of everything, You are awesome, mighty, just, and compassionate. You alone are King and gracious.
verses.comment: This prayer reflects core Jewish beliefs on God's uniqueness, attributes, and sovereignty.

verses.text: You alone are generous, you alone are just, almighty, and eternal. You rescue Israel from every hardship; you chose the ancestors and made them holy.
verses.comment: The themes of redemption and election recall Genesis and the Exodus stories.

verses.text: Accept this sacrifice for all the people of Israel, protect your chosen heritage, and make it holy.
verses.comment: The offering is interpreted as atonement and intercession for all Israel.

verses.text: Gather our scattered nation, liberate those enslaved among foreign nations, look with compassion on the rejected and despised, and let the Gentiles know that you alone are our God.
verses.comment: A petition for restoration and vindication, anticipating messianic hopes.

verses.text: Judge those who oppress us, those who treat others with arrogant pride.
verses.comment: Prays for divine justice against oppressors, consistent with prophetic literature.

verses.text: Establish your people in your holy land, just as you promised through Moses.”
verses.comment: References Mosaic promises of the land, summing up the prayer for restoration.

verses.text: The priests then sang hymns.
verses.comment: Musical worship followed the sacrificial ritual, typical of temple liturgy.

verses.text: Once the offering was completely burned, Nehemiah directed that the leftover liquid be poured on large stones.
verses.comment: Closing act of the ritual, further demonstrating the miraculous qualities of the liquid.

verses.text: When this was done, a fire flared up. However, when the altar’s light shone on it, the fire died out.
verses.comment: A double miracle—shows dependence on God's glory for sustaining the fire, connecting to Shekinah.

verses.text: When this event was reported, and the king of Persia learned how the liquid discovered in the priests' old hiding place had ignited the sacrifice, just as Nehemiah and his companions had done,
verses.comment: The Persian king acts as interested benefactor, confirming the event's historical impact and miracle.

verses.text: he investigated, enclosed the site, and declared it sacred.
verses.comment: Royal recognition of the miracle—underscores cross-cultural reverence and Jewish distinctiveness.

verses.text: The king also exchanged many fine gifts with those he favored.
verses.comment: Reports diplomatic and material consequences of sacred events, a typical motif in ancient historical narratives.

verses.text: Nehemiah and his followers named the substance 'nephthar', meaning purification; but most people call it naphtha.
verses.comment: The name highlights the sacred character and connects to wider chemical and ritual traditions across cultures.
